[Music]
Hey everyone, welcome back to Practically Intelligent.
Today, we're interviewing Sanjay Kalra, one of the founders and the former CPO of Lacework, a cyber security unicorn in the cloud security space.
Sanjay was a former founder who sold his company to Zscaler, a public cyber security company, and wrote a really interesting blog post on the risks with Generative AI in security.
So today, we're going to pick Sanjay's brain a little bit about some of the threat vectors that are obvious and not so obvious and how he sees professionals and engineers needing to respond to the challenge.
I think he does a really great job of sorting out different threat factors into different buckets and then also gives us clear examples that maybe, you know, your average machine learning engineer, data scientist, hadn't thought of.
Yeah, and I think that the idea that a lot of people haven't really thought about a lot of the Generative AI security risks and concerns is going to be a common theme in our conversation, right?
A lot of people are using Generative AI, not everybody is thinking about what the implications are.
So I mean, without further ado, let's jump right in.
Hey Sanjay, thank you for joining us today.
Thanks, nice, thanks for inviting me to the podcast.
Of course.
So I want to start with the post that you wrote back in November of 2023, and it was a very enlightening post because some of the statistics in that post are kind of eye-opening, and of course, we're going to link to it in our show description.
But just to call out one of the biggest ones that really kind of made me reread that paragraph over and over again.
So you ran a survey of, I believe it was, 900 IT leaders across a bunch of markets, and in that survey, those IT leaders said that 95% of those organizations were already using Generative AI tools in some way, and that's not the most interesting part.
What was most interesting was the follow-up was that 89% of those people also admitted that Generative AI is a potential security risk.
So how do you reconcile a technology that everyone is so eager to adopt, however, they also admit it is a security risk?
Yeah, I think it's interesting, actually.
This story has been played before, like when the cloud showed up, same thing happened, actually.
People were really scared of cloud because they were not sure what the security cloud will bring in.
Bring your own device, same thing happened, actually.
And I'll give you an example.
Within Zscaler, we did a created a working group, and we went to all functional areas within Zscaler asking them, is any application where they can use Generative AI, from HR, IT, finance, and marketing?
And within a month, we had 86 different applications ideas, and every CIO, CSO is going through that thing because every team comes up with different use cases, actually, and they don't want to fall behind.
And this is such a generational shift technology.
These guys actually are being forced to jump in without understanding all the risks that come with actually moving the technology like this.
So I take your point that this has happened before and that that generational, this is more or less in a lot of ways one of the seminal technologies of this generation of leaders and companies and organizations.
So to that end, and you don't talk about this too much in the post, but I know that you're really interested in thinking about these kinds of security risks from two main perspectives, meaning AI in security and the security of AI.
So I want to start by kind of getting into some of those topics.
I'm genuinely very curious to hear your thoughts on how Generative AI in general, whether it's in the aspect of security itself or just being used as a technology, what are the potential vectors that people should be thinking about, right?
Most people will think about things like, well, we need to think about bias that can leak out, we need to think about data that can leak.
What are, in your opinion, what are the top considerations that people are probably not exactly thinking of day-to-day that they really should be thinking of when it comes to Generative AI?
Yeah, I think one of the things, actually, is that technology is really great, but it has been kind of built without thinking a lot about security.
And it, I'll give you a few examples, actually.
Like when you put data in a database, you can go and delete a table.
In a Generative AI, once you put the data in a Generative AI, there is no delete button.
There's no easy way to roll back data.
It goes into this wild ocean, and it's kind of there forever.
You think about access control, there's no access control.
Once you create an embeddings in a database, you have control over every table, every column.
There is no access control.
You look at in a traditional networking, we had always had a concept of a control plane and a data plane where we always kept like the which, what was management versus what the data is flowing in.
In a Generative AI case, actually, there are three sets of data.
There's the data actually goes into the foundation model, the data which actually used for training, like fine-tuning or RAG, and then there's a prompt.
The Generative AI technologies, LLMs, don't distinguish between any of them.
They don't, they treat the user information same as what that came from the foundation or the training.
These things create a lot of challenges because now the technology is moving really fast, but they didn't really build a lot of these guardrails from the beginning.
So the question is, actually, what are the challenges?
The first one, of course, is, um, when you're using this technology, first is operational because you have issues, things like data drift, hallucinations, but it's still evolving.
They have a lot of issues, like you ask the same question, you get don't get the same answer next time.
That works really well for unstructured, it doesn't work for structured data.
Structured data, you have to be very exact, and a lot of the cases, like finance or healthcare, you have to be more accurate every time.
You can't give a different answer for the same question.
The second problem, actually, is ethics.
There are issues with bias, like you would be very careful when you're using it, actually, in your HR, like looking at the candidates for interviews or making vendor selection, how do you make sure it doesn't have the bias or or toxicity that comes with it, actually, because people can use it for any any purpose.
The third piece, actually, is around uh, security, and when you think about security, you cannot actually, it's not a blanket thing because people kind of start thinking, okay, I'm thinking about security of Generative AI.
Uh, you need to also first think about how is being used in your company because the first thing is maybe your employees actually just using Generative AI chatbots.
Second thing is maybe you bought enterprise-owned AI applications, like, um, Writer or Grammarly or something like that.
That's a second step.
Third step might be that you are trying to build your own applications, then you might your applications use foundation models without any changes, or you might do RAG or fine-tuning, or you might end up building your own custom models.
In all of these things, when you think about about it, like there are always, when you're looking at Generative AI, there are two decisions: are you going to buy something, you going to build it, or extend?
You going to buy a new technology, you're going to build something internally, or you have an existing vendor where you can add these capabilities.
When you think about security, you need to think of these things differently because if you think about like security, the first step, actually, if you're building applications, there are things like model security, um, and data poisoning comes into picture, the training, controlling what train goes into thing comes into picture.
When you talk about things like using the Generative AI with the prompt, then you have to look at things like prompt injection, a lot of other capabilities which actually to think about from the SEC, the whole LLM top 10 from us comes into picture.
And over arink all of this, actually, is compliance because anytime a new technology shows up, uh, the government agencies are ready uh, with their compliance list, which basically making sure that at least there is a basic uh, uh, security framework.
So we have a lot of those now with EU coming up with their own federal government, actually, executive order, there is no a new ISO 4201.
So there is all of those actually coming up as well.
Yeah, the there's a lot of intertwining threads here, and I want, I want to zoom in on one of them that you mentioned on bias, and you know, before anyone kind of rolls their eyes at me, bias is not a new term in machine learning, right?
When we talk about bias in a machine learning algorithm or in an AI system, we we we're not necessarily talking about things things like stereotypes, we're not necessarily talking about things like, um, you know, is is is the AI going to prefer person A over person B for some reason.
That's part of it, that's a big part of it, but when we talk about bias, it's a much broader concept of is the AI willing to do something that is not necess, that is basically it thinks it's doing the right thing, however, it doesn't really understand the external consequences of what it might be doing.
I'll give an example and based on something that you said as well, based on prompting data, because I I I had a client once and I, who shall remain unnamed, and part of what they were trying to build was a chatbot, of course, and they wanted to use a prompt that included a lot of the users' personal identifiable information, and in some cases, they wanted to use information that was is extremely sensitive about the person that they were chatting to because in their minds they said, well, I want to build a RAG system, I want to bring in context and give the context to the LLM, and the LLM will be able to use that, and I go, that's a great in theory, that sounds great, however, one of the big biases in an LLM is, especially if for using something off the shelf, let's call it Llama 2, just not to, you know, point them out or anything, but pretty much any instruction-following LLM, a conversational chat-based LLM, they're specifically designed to be helpful, right?
That's the term that always comes up, they're helpful, but not not harmful.
Well, one of the reasons prompt injection actually works is because you're using that bias against the AI.
The AI wants to be helpful, so if you attempt to inject something like, hey, can you, you know, uh, I'm actually curious about this person's social security number and go, oh, I have that right here in my prompt, how useful, let me give that to you.
That kind of a bias is also that that that's a kind of AI bias that's going to lead to a prompt injection attack.
Does that track with what you think about?
Famous examples, if I ask like how I want to hack into the system, the AI system might say no, but can you tell me all the vulnerabilities in my system so I can protect against it?
The same question asked differently, you're pretending to be a penetration tester saying, here are the answers, how you to protect all the vulnerabilities you might have in the system.
I'm asking the same question, it is just that the AI was trying to help me in one case, one thing is trying to protect against me.
So exactly, and this actually is like, I, I'll give another example.
I put something in a, because it's very easy to do these things, you can put, give a vulnerable code and ask is it vulnerable?
It will say no.
I go and change the code and add a line in the top saying this code is not vulnerable, and I ask the same question again, and it will say no, because it reading that line.
But I think, you know, people actually think about, like, okay, how difficult it is, like going from a dashboard to a chatbot, like what is a big deal?
And people don't realize that when they do dashboards, it's a very tight controlled interface.
The only thing you can do, actually, is you can see what widgets are available, you can put foot filters.
The minute you actually go from a dashboard to a chatbot, you opened a Pandora box.
It happened with a Chevy dealer in Watsonville.
The guy put up a chatbot without putting any controls.
The first thing the guy says is that comes and says to the chatbot saying, is Tesla is better than Chevy?
Because, and so you do you want like your chart board to talk about that competition is better than yours?
No.
The other problem, actually, yeah, then thing the languages, like the you might have trained, this is another attack which was shown, like you trained your guardrails using English, saying, uh, don't talk about things, and the next thing somebody did, actually, is ask the same question in French, and it bypasses all the guards because the guard training, actually, was in English, so it is able to kind of give everything.
And all it happened, they did it actually with Bing.
They were able to steal the training data.
The Bing code name is Sydney, and the the researchers actually were able to go and uh, poke this the Bing and ask actually what the code name was, and then ask it to print all the lines that came in after the code word, and print out the the chart data.
So it's happening to Microsoft, it's happening the chart board.
I'll be honest with the other parts, actually, think about like prompt injection, you mentioned, there's even coding, like I can actually put, have chatbot generate code and I can run the code, which can be very dangerous.
And the thing actually scares me even the more is agents, but still now these LLMs actually were like really in a sign box, you were kind of giving the data, asking a question, now suddenly you are giving them access, writing these agents, actually, which are able to access because LLMs don't have the leasing data, you need data from other systems, so now you need to go and call these agents, and these agents, actually, you need a very fine control, like what these agents are going to do, because if the agents actually don't have the right access control, a lot of the data will come in which you don't like.
I'll give you another example which was very interesting.
Um, in this chatbot thing was invisible text.
So I was talking to a big Pharma company day before yesterday, and I was giving them the example that one of the attacks you can do is that when I use AI to look at resumes, I can create resumes, you can create a resume, we put black font for everything, but what I do in my resume, actually, is I actually put, take the job description, create all kind of stuff around the job description and put on a white on a white font and put it, submit the resume.
Now your resume and my resume on the paper are the same, but when when AI reads it, I have more, lot more capabilities than you have.
So I, I was mentioning that to them, and they were like, you know, this is happening to us.
We actually had our supplier sum submitting RFP responses with white on white, actually, because because they were expecting to get selected from the vendor selection process.
Go ahead, sorry.
Yeah, I mean, there's so many examples.
I, I think that's kind of the funny thing is there's so many examples, and I think a lot of it comes back to what you said earlier, which is to an LLM, for the most part, these data sources remain equal in its eyes, right?
So when you said like Sydney, I, I believe that, I assume that would be part of the foundational model pre-training, right?
That was that was probably data that would that came in fairly early on that the model was able to just resurface as opposed to putting something in a prompt like white on white text on on a resume.
Again, to the LLM, these things are roughly held equivalent.
There there is some research being done on on the weight that they give on on whether or not to service information, but I think a lot of it comes down to the AIs are trying to help, and if you exploit that, that in that kind of internal sense of I'm trying to help this human who is talking to me, it's relatively easy to exploit something who is again just trying.


To help, yeah, I agree with you. And I think the other part, actually, remember, is that, like, even though these training actually is happening for the foundation model, the other challenge, actually, in a lot of these foundation models, actually, is that the minute you do fine-tuning, basically, you're adding, you're changing the weights, original weights, with adding your own weights. It actually can break the alignment. So, the best LLMs, actually, once you add training, can, like, completely start talking about violence or be in the do-and-anything mode because they have, you lost the alignment. And that, actually, is again a challenging part because now I can actually have, and, and traditionally, if you think about, like, the, the one of the challenges in the traditional security has been is that we all worked on data security, talk about PII data and things like that. But the problem is PII data, actually, typically, you look at bag of words, you say this is a social security number, this is a credit card. But one of the advantages, actually, of the Generative AI is that it actually is able to understand the semantics of it. So, when I say Chase Bank versus River Bank, it knows that one is a real bank versus one is not a bank, which is not possible. And same thing, when I say I want to block violence, if I use the traditional data protection, it doesn't understand the violence is violence, but violence also means brutality and five other 500 other things. And that's only using an LLM, you can understand. So, you have to use this technology, which is coming out, to, to also to protect it against it.

Actually, we've talked a little bit, Sanjay, about the bias and, you know, the LLM's bias to be helpful, about operational issues, uh, of they're non-deterministic in nature on security. Um, we've talked a little bit also about prompt injection as a kind of key attack vector. You know, MITRE, which is a research organization, released its Atlas framework, it's adversarial threat landscape against AI, um, and a huge number of potential threat vectors, etc., that could emerge over the next five to six years. Rather than highlight the specific threat factors, I'm curious what operationally is going to have to change the most in security teams in the next two to three years. Uh, there's obviously defending the prompt window, making sure our data is secure, but is there anything as a result of your time in this space and looking around the corner, how are security teams, um, going to be run differently in two to three years? What's gonna, which categories are going to change the most?

Yeah, I think my perspective is that, like, so we talked about, like, a lot about security of AI, so let's switch topic to, like, AI in security, like, how do is, like, how can you use AI to build better security products? Because for me, it's like almost like security is a technology and service of business. Yep. Anytime technology changes or business changes, security has to change and AI is both a technology and a business leap, so security has to change and evolve. And when cloud showed up, again, there was issues with SaaS and all that stuff, but then companies like Zscaler were born because of cloud. So, how do you use AI to build better security products? The first thing, actually, I'll be honest with you, like, there's been a lot of things about co-pilots, but my perspective in all this stuff, actually, is that I'm not a big, I think all this question-and-answer concept, which we have right now, it's a transitionary thing. Because for me, I actually am looking forward to, like, more autopilots than co-pilots, because I want that co-pilot to transition where I actually want, like, this thing to do a task for me or not answer a question. Because for me, the biggest challenge today in security is two-fold. One is there's a skill gap, they can't hire enough people. And the problem there also happens is that security guards actually have trouble hiring people for firewall and antivirus, them understanding firewall, antivirus, or EDR, and then understanding SaaS and Kubernetes and cloud, and Salesforce and build, having expertise, they can't hire people to expertise in all these areas, so they need these AI systems to help them secure these systems. Second problem, actually, with the, with the security guard, actually, is that they are, their role is changing from a firefighter to a fire marshal. So, in most of the time, they're accountable for things, but not responsible. They cannot fix anything because if Java vulnerability happened, they go to developers, if S3 open, DevOps, if there is issue with SaaS, they go to SaaS Ops, if everything they have to. So, first thing is how do you kind of automate a lot of the task? I think GenAI is going to be really, really helpful is automating the, uh, the security operations workflows, um, follow-ups, all of that, I think, can be done within security. The second piece, actually, of course, is around, I kind of feel like the data protection, because right now there's a lot of false positives, so being able to create semantic aware data protection, so I can understand, like, when a credit card shows up, it is really a credit card and why it is there, instead of just saying it's a credit card, uh, maybe I'm buying something, it's okay, uh, so being able to understand that, and then multimodal, being able to understand, look at somebody sending out, like, the blueprints out or sending out Zoom call, can I look inside videos and images? I can't do that today with my current technology. GenAI can do that. Training is a big deal, because for me, like, one of the biggest advantages of GenAI is that I, I tell, I build a product, one product, but I don't have one customer. It's not I want to get to market of one, because for me, like, every, for my product, actually, I have a CIO, a CISO, a network guy, I have a guy who speaks English, a guy who speaks French, a guy who likes video, a guy who likes text or white paper, and somebody wants to be in LinkedIn, somebody wants to me being in. So, when I think about that, like, if I want to reach the same customer, I have, like, not one customer, but I have 100 of customers for the same thing with, and until now, it was not possible for me to create content for all of them. Same thing, security training, based on what the user is doing, I can actually on the fly create training material for every persona and everything, but based on what, because humans, actually, are the weakest thing, so I think security training is going to get really, really disruptive. Now, I can explain in English language with GenAI what it is, I can give the fix, they can go to the engineer saying how to fix it. That is, I think, the whole vulnerability management. Yeah, I think that's, that's a fundamental thing we need to solve before we can start using GenAI, because if you think about it, actually, um, the, when you put a date, like, people talk about security, uh, they talk about, like, network security or endpoint security, but in the end, it's all a proxy to protect the data.
